questions.question:
Question 1: A child injures his knee while playing. A few days later, the wound on his knee shows signs of 
inflammation. The wound is cultured and its Gram-stained smear is given below. Further 
testing shows that the cultured organism is coagulase-positive. Identify the organism.
questions.explanation:
An infected wound culture showing Gram-positive cocci arranged in clusters which are 
coagulase-positive suggest that the cultured organism is Staphylococcus aureus. 120 
Sold by @itachibot Staphylococci are Gram-positive cocci that are catalase-positive. They grow in clusters because the 
cells divide successively in three perpendicular planes, with the daughter cells remaining attached 
to one another following each successive division. Among the 45 different species of 
Staphylococcus, Staphylococcus aureus is the only one which is coagulase positive. Other options: Option A: Streptococci are catalase negative. They are Gram-positive cocci arranged in chains. Options C & D: S. epidermidis and S. saprophyticus are both coagulase negative. Different bacteria with their typical arrangements are given below: • Staphylococcus: Clusters • Streptococcus: Chains • Pneumococcus: Pairs/lanceolate shaped • Micrococcus: Tetrads

questions.question:
Question 2: The specimen obtained by performing incision and drainage of a breast abscess was sent for 
culture on nutrient agar. An image of the culture plate is given below. Microscopy of the 
isolated organism revealed gram-positive cocci arranged in clusters. Which of the following is 
a false statement regarding this organism? 115 
Sold by @itachibot

options.b: Golden yellow pigmentation is due to -carotene
options.c: Pigment production is enhanced by adding milk to culture media
options.d: Confluent growth presents a characteristic 'oil-paint appearance'

questions.explanation:
Gram-positive cocci arranged in clusters that produce golden-yellow pigment on nutrient agar is 
suggestive of Staphylococcus aureus. The pigment production occurs optimally at 22°C. Staphylococcus aureus is a Gram-positive coccus. On nutrient agar, its colonies are large (2-4 mm 
in diameter), convex, smooth, shiny, opaque and easily emulsifiable. The colonies appear golden 
yellow due to the presence of staphyloxanthin (carotenoid). Pigment production occurs optimally 
at 22°C and in aerobic conditions. It is enhanced when 1% glycerol or milk is incorporated in the 
medium. On a nutrient agar slope, there is confluent growth of Staphylococcus, which appears as a 
characteristic oil-paint appearance. 121 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question: Question 3: Which factor forms the basis of co-agglutination reaction shown by Staphylococcus aureus?
questions.explanation:
Protein A forms the basis of the co-agglutination reaction shown by Staphylococcus aureus. Protein A bearing staphylococci are coated with IgG antiserum. Protein A binds to the Fc terminal 
of IgG, leaving the Fab terminal free to combine with its specific antigen. The corresponding 
antigen is then added to this mixture which causes agglutination of the bacteria. This is known as 
the co-agglutination reaction. It is used for streptococcal, gonococcal or hemophilus typing.

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following toxins exhibits hot-cold phenomenon?
questions.explanation:
-hemolysin exhibits a hot-cold phenomenon. -hemolysin is a sphingomyelinase that is hemolytic only for sheep cells but not human cells. It 
initiates hemolysis at 370C but the hemolysis is evident only after chilling. This is called the 
hot-cold phenomenon.

questions.question:
Question 5: Which of the following pairs of toxins produced by Staphylococcus aureus are called 
synergohymenotropic toxins?
questions.explanation:
-toxin and Panton-Valentine-toxin (leucocidin) of Staphylococcus aureus are called 
synergohymenotropic toxins. Synergohymenotropic (synergo - working together, hymenotropic - form pores) toxins are a family 
of bicomponent toxins that act through the synergistic activity of 2 non-associated secretory 
proteins - class F and class S proteins. Gamma hemolysin has two components necessary for its 
hemolytic action. It is encoded by three genes HlgA and HlgC (belonging to class S) and HlgB 
(belonging to class F), resulting in 2 pairs of class S and F components - HlgA and HlgB, or HlgC 
and HlgB. 122 
Sold by @itachibot Panton-Valentine Leucocidin is composed of two components- S and F - encoded by two 
contiguous and cotranscribed genes, lukS-PV and lukF-PV. It is associated with the majority of 
community-associated methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (CA-MRSA).

questions.question: Question 6: Which of the following staphylococcal infections is not toxin mediated?
questions.explanation:
Staphylococcal septicemia is not toxin mediated. Septicemia occurs due to the invasion of bacterial organisms into the bloodstream. This causes an 
inflammatory response to bacterial products, leading to various manifestations seen in sepsis - 
fever, hypotension, alkalosis. Toxin mediated staphylococcal infections include food poisoning caused by enterotoxin, toxic 
shock syndrome caused by toxic shock syndrome toxin and staphylococcal scalded skin syndrome 
caused by exfoliative/epidermolytic toxin.

questions.question:
Question 7: A college student with a history of intravenous drug abuse presents with a fever for the last 3 
weeks. Echocardiography is performed which reveals large friable vegetations on the cusps of 
the tricuspid valve. Which of the following organisms is the most common cause for this 
condition?
questions.explanation:
Fever with vegetations on the tricuspid valve points to a diagnosis of right-sided infective 
endocarditis. Staphylococcus aureus is the most common cause of right-sided infective 
endocarditis among intravenous drug abusers. Infective endocarditis is the microbial infection of heart valves or endocardium, leading to the 
formation of vegetations (thrombotic debris and microbial organisms).The following image shows 
a graphical illustration of vegetations seen in infective endocarditis.

questions.question:
Question 8: By which of the following mechanisms is penicillin resistance commonly transferred to 
Staphylococcus aureus?
questions.explanation:
123 
Sold by @itachibot Penicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus is determined by plasmids that are most commonly 
transferred by transduction. Penicillin resistance in Staphylococci most commonly occurs due to bacterial production of 
beta-lactamase, which inactivates penicillins by splitting their beta-lactam ring. These enzymes 
are inducible and are plasmid-mediated. They confer resistance to penicillin G, ampicillin, 
piperacillin etc. The genetic transfer of antibiotic resistance can occur in the following ways: • Transformation: After death or cell lysis, some bacteria release their DNA into the environment. 
Other bacteria, generally of the same species, can come into contact with these free DNA 
fragments, take them up and incorporate them into their DNA by recombination. • Transduction: This method involves the transfer of DNA, episome or plasmid from one 
bacterium to another with the use of a bacteriophage. • Conjugation: This mechanism requires the presence of a special plasmid called the F plasmid 
that codes for the sex pilus. It is the most common method of transfer of antibiotic resistance in 
most other bacteria. Note: Change in penicillin binding proteins (PBPs) and production of -lactamases are modes of 
penicillin resistance seen in S. aureus but the question asks for methods of transfer of drug 
resistance.

questions.question: Question 9: Contact based isolation is employed for which of the following diseases?
questions.explanation:
Contact based isolation is employed for patients who are infected with 
MRSA (methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus). The three categories of transmission-based precautions include: • Contact-based isolation is used for infections, diseases, or germs that are spread by touching the 
patient or items in the room. Examples include MRSA, vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE), 
diarrheal illnesses, open wounds, and respiratory syncytial virus (RSV). • Droplet-based isolation is employed for diphtheria and mumps. • Airborne precautions are required to protect against conditions like measles, severe acute 
respiratory syndrome (SARS), varicella (chickenpox), and Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

questions.question:
Question 10: An outbreak of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus infection was reported in the 
surgical ward of a hospital. Which of the following precautionary measures would you 
recommend to best curb its spread?

options.a: Administration of vancomycin empirically to all the patients
options.c: Wearing masks before performing invasive procedures
options.d: Washing of hands before & after treating the patients

questions.explanation:
Among the given options, washing hands before and after treating the patients is the most 
effective way to curb the spread of methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) infections. In addition to this, personnel with active S. aureus lesions and carriers should be excluded from 
areas having patients at highest risk for severe staphylococcal infections like newborn nurseries, 
intensive care units, operating rooms, and cancer chemotherapy wards. In such individuals, the 
application of topical antiseptics such as mupirocin to nasal or perineal carriage sites may 
diminish the shedding of MRSA. 124 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 11: A 32-year-old man presented with multiple tender, erythematous fluctuant skin lesions as 
shown in the image. You suspect it to be a case of botryomycosis. Which of the following is 
the most likely organism implicated in this condition? 118 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The most common cause of botryomycosis is Staphylococcus aureus. Botryomycosis is a rare chronic bacterial granulomatous disease that usually involves the skin and 
rarely viscera. It is most commonly caused by Staphylococcus aureus but can also be caused by 
Pseudomonas, Escherichia coli, Proteus, and Streptococci. Patients present with chronic, 
suppurative, granulomatous skin lesions like nodules, abscesses and sinuses. Actinomycetoma, eumycetoma and botryomycosis are difficult to distinguish clinically but are 
readily distinguished with microbiologic testing or biopsy. Granules of botryomycosis consist of 
loose masses of cocci. Organisms can also be seen in wound discharge or histologic specimens.

questions.question:
Question 12: A 14-year-old boy presents with a history of vomiting within 3 hours of consumption of food 
at a party. Which of the following organism is most likely to cause these symptoms?
questions.explanation:
Vomiting 2 hours after the consumption of food is likely food poisoning by Staphylococcus 
aureus. Staphylococcus aureus can grow in carbohydrate and protein food sources, producing 
enterotoxins. There are 15 types, all of which are superantigens. They are preformed toxins that 
are relatively heat stable. They stimulate the vagus nerve, vomiting centre of the brain and 
intestinal peristaltic activity. Type A enterotoxin is responsible for most cases of food poisoning. The common sources of infection are the foods that are not cooked after handling. These include 
sliced meats, puddings, pastries, and sandwiches. Ingestion of such contaminated food causes 
food poisoning within 30 minutes to 6 hours after consumption. Patients present with nausea, 
vomiting, stomach cramps, and diarrhoea.

questions.question:
Question 13: An 18-year-old girl presented with burning micturition and fever with chills for three days. 
Urine culture grew bacteria which were coagulase-negative and novobiocin-resistant. Which 
of the following is the most likely organism implicated here?
questions.explanation:
Burning micturition and fever with chills in a young woman points to a diagnosis of urinary tract 
infection (UTI). The most likely organism implicated here is Staphylococcus saprophyticus as it is 
coagulase-negative and novobiocin-resistant. Staphylococcus saprophyticus is a part of the normal flora of human skin and periurethral area 
and thus is a common cause of urinary tract infection (UTI) in young women. 125 
Sold by @itachibot Option A: Staphylococcus aureus is a coagulase-positive bacterium. It is an uncommon cause of 
UTI. Options B and C: Staphylococcus hominis and Staphylococcus epidermidis are coagulase-negative 
and novobiocin-sensitive. They are usually considered contaminants if found on urine culture but 
they may also cause UTIs in children with underlying urinary tract abnormalities.

questions.question: Question 14: Choose the incorrect statement regarding Micrococci.
questions.explanation:
Micrococci are arranged in pairs, tetrads or clusters of eight. Micrococci are Gram-positive cocci that are often mistaken for S. aureus. However, they are larger 
in size and mostly occur in pairs, tetrads or clusters of eight. They form smaller colonies in culture 
in comparison to S. aureus. Hugh-Leifson oxidation-fermentation test can be used 
to differentiate between micrococci (oxidative pattern) and staphylococci (fermentative pattern). Micrococci are catalase-positive and modified oxidase-positive. They are ordinarily 
non-pathogenic but can rarely cause infections in an immunocompromised host. They are part of 
normal bacterial flora in the body. The following image shows the tetrad arrangement of micrococci: 126 
Sold by @itachibot Different bacteria with their typical arrangements are given below: 1. Staphylococcus: Clusters 2. Streptococcus: Chains 3. Pneumococcus: Pairs/lanceolate shaped 4. Micrococcus: Tetrads 127 
Sold by @itachibot Corynebacterium, Listeria and Actinomyces
